conclusion: Determine the work done by the frictional force on the object as it is transported from point M to point N.
Calculate the frictional force F_f using the formula F_f = mu * m * g.
Given mu = 0.3, m = 3 kg, g = 10 m/s^2.
Determine net force F_net = 9 N, since no other horizontal force is mentioned.
Using Newton's second law, calculate acceleration a = F_net / m = 9 / 3 = 3 m/s^2.
Determine displacement s using the kinematic equation v^2 = u^2 + 2as.
Initial velocity u = 0, final velocity v = 6 m/s.
Object slides for 6 meters before reaching the speed of the conveyor belt.
Calculate additional distance traveled once object reaches conveyor belt speed: L - s = 10 - 6 = 4 m.
During this time, the object moves at the speed of the conveyor belt (6 m/s).
Calculate work done by frictional force: W = F_f * L_s.
L_s is the distance over which the frictional force acts, which is the same as the distance the object slides.
Calculate work done: W = 9 N * 6 m = 54 J.
The work done by the frictional force of the conveyor belt on the object is 54 J.
